Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 10:21AM GrandHillMom wrote: I also failed Tamoxifen but had regression then stability on Aromasin. I had carbo/taxol last summer for unrelated ovarian cancer, which also got me to NED for my metastatic BC. I have continued NED since last October on Aromasin.
Posts.Title: NED, ER+/HER2-? Are you out there? I want to know you! DancingVeggie Stormynyte

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2014 05:57PM GrandHillMom wrote: Zometa does cause stress fractures, which are known side effects.   I have had two in my foot.  I have gone from monthly to quarterly Zometa treatments and have not had another for over a year.  I have to be very careful not to twist the foot so cannot wear high heels or even Dansko clogs.  I agree that running may not be in the cards and you will need to find something with less impact.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: How often should I take Zometa? Springlakegirl Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 11:46PM GrandHillMom wrote: I quit working, but am taking a lot of vacations!  If you enjoy work, I say go for it.  I did not really enjoy my work and it worked out financially to take disability and retirement income.  I am loving not having to work and being on LTD for the last 18 months.  By the way, I am another Penny.
Posts.Title: Working? Vacations? redwolf8812 GrandHillMom

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2010 09:31AM GrandHillMom wrote: I was very sad and emotional yesterday morning (Christmas Eve day).  I am also now on LTD, but didn't seem to get enough things organized for Christmas.  I worked all day yesterday and am still baking,etc. for today's dinner with my husband's family.  I cried yesterday, something I don't do often, because I am scared about the future.  I have a 12 year old, a 21 year old and a 27 year old, and I just think the 12 year old is getting a bum deal (and so are the other two).  I also lost my Mom to the side effects of breast cancer treatment, but she was only Stage 1 and died from a pulmonary embolism from an Arenesp shot--really, really shitty unfair! But I also think lucky I am to have all three kids around this year, a great husband, a special puppy, many friends, and a very very white Christmas here in the North Star State.  Jennifer, I hope you have at least as many good days and bad ones, and lots and lots of time with your husband and your pups.  I think it is hard for anyone not in our shoes to understand what we are going through, so always feel free to say how you feel to us.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 04:36PM GrandHillMom wrote: I am 54 year old "retired" attorney (took disability 2 1/2 years ago after mets dx).  I am now stay at home mom to busy 14 year old daughter.   I also have a 29 year old son and a 23 year old stepdaughter, both living out of state now.  My husband and I have had our ups and downs, but are currently hanging in there together.  I was dx'd with bilateral Stage IIIb and IIa IDC in 2006, had aggressive chemo, surgery and radiation, and then almost to the day four years later dx'd with widespread bone mets.  Also dx'd with clear cell ovarian cancer earlier this year.  After chemo for the  ovarian cancer, my mets were metabolically inactive (NED, in other words). I was stable prior to that.  I continue on Aromasin and Zometa, with another PET scheduled next month to see what the bone mets are up to.   I am not a frequent poster but read almost every post.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2013 03:33PM GrandHillMom wrote: I tried Cymbalta, Gabapentin (similar to Neurontin) and Lyrica. None of them helped with my arm pain and tingling, which I assumed was peripheral neuropathy. I had a full neurological work up and it turns out I have a vitamin B12 deficiency. This can cause serious neurological issues and is probably caused by an autoimmune disease called pernicious anemia. I just started B12 shots. My neurologist says it will probably take a few weeks to see improvement. A simple blood test showed the defiency. You need to fast before the test. Maybe you could ask for this blood test to rule out a B12 issue.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 06:22PM GrandHillMom wrote: I have been going to the infusion room for years--stage 3b BC for ACT (no hair), stage iv MetastatIc BC for Zometa (hair) and now have added stage 1 clear cell ovarian cancer and carbo/taxol ( no hair again). I always think every one else looks sicker than me, hair or no hair. I like to go alone, and people who bring several friends or family members when there is really only room for one companion per patient really annoy me. The tvs have head sets, thanks goodness. I just take snack (odorless) and read a book or try to sleep. My current treatment takes at least five hours, which is a long day if you get next to the loud talkers, nosy people, or someone who brings or orders in smelly food!

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 12:52PM GrandHillMom wrote: I have skull mets, but have never been more concerned about them than my other bone mets (spine, ribs, pelvis and femurs). They are bone mets, which are treatable for a long time, as you know. They are NOT brain mets. Please do not let them upset you. You should plan for the future, but I do not believe the skull mets have significantly changed that future. Stay strong.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 01:53AM GrandHillMom wrote: A port is a great thing! I am on port no. 3. First one removed after initial a/c and taxol when I had breast reconstruction. When I was diagnosed stage iv four years later, I got a new one (power port now) on the same side but it didn't work super great. I only use for monthly blood draws and Zometa, so don't really have to have one. I decided to go for no. 3 anyway, even though some nurses and my breast surgeon tried to talk me out of it. Before my insertion surgery, it took two nurses and several pokes to get the IV in. I told them that is why I need one! The new one is on the other side and works perfectly. No pain or anxiety for blood draws and infusions. I have never even had the numbing cream some people use. I just wish the PET scan contrast could be infused through it. My hospital says the glucose in the contrast would clog up the port. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 11:24PM - edited Aug 22, 2012 12:27AM by GrandHillMom Those of you who acknowledged that being Stage iv "from the get go" might be better in some ways than presenting at a lower stage and having every harsh treatment before mets are found: Thank you! I often think I would have preferred to have been initially diagnosed at stage iv rather than stage IIIb, so I could have avoided at least some of the treatments and also the intervening worries (really, knowledge ) that It would metatasticize anyway. I have never wanted to say this to anyone initially diagnosed as stage iv, so I am grateful for your comments.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 09:10AM GrandHillMom wrote: Returned last week from 16 days in Europe.  First to Paris with my husband and 13 year old daughter for 4 days, then met husband's entire family in Rome to attend my brother in law's wedding at the castle where Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes got married.  Unbelieveable!  Spent several days in Rome and a couple in Florence with my sister-in-law, two brothers-in-law and five nieces/nephews--that made 6 kids between 15 and 10 hanging out together.  Only problem was I developed a very sore foot about 5 days into the trip.  Had an x-ray in Rome which didn't show any fractures, so continued walking on it for 10 more days.  When I got home, went to my doctor who referred me to a podiatrist.  New x-rays showed stress fracture in right fifth metatarsal.  Now in a walking boot for several weeks.  My onc wonders how I got a stress fracture while taking Zometa, now wants a bone density test in case the Aromasin is seriously thinning my bones.  Back to reality, I guess.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 07:11PM GrandHillMom wrote: I had the test and counseling after being dx'd with ovarian cancer on top of my BC. Also, my mom had BC-and my dad died from metastatic prostate cancer. All these add up to a good probability for BRCA mutations. I mostly wanted to know for my kids, nieces and nephews. The medical reason given to insurance is that the results may affect treatment decisions now or in the future. Turns out I am not BRCA 1 or 2 positive, and knowing that has benefited me because it is good news for my kids and nieces and nephews.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 01:39PM GrandHillMom wrote: I have been on long term disability for 21 months. Having stage iv bc is at least a part time job, so it is hard to also have a full time job, especially if you have to do the job at specific times, like at a school. I do not sit home all day. I take writing classes, go to the gym to take "silver sneakers" fitness classes even though I am the youngest by 20 years, travel, see old coworkers, garden, read a lot of books, etc. Some days I hang out at home, but I find that if I put something on my calendar like a yoga class, I will go. You could volunteer at your school or another school. I have done some volunteering at my 13 year old's school. I hope your pet says there is no problem, but keep thinking about disability and how you can use your time and live with less stress. I am happy with my choice.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 01:09AM - edited Mar 8, 2011 01:10AM by GrandHillMom I have a lot of respect for what Lance has gone through, and he is a great inspiration, but Stage IV testicular cancer is considered curable while Stage IV breast cancer is not.  Testicular cancer is actually one of the most curable cancers, and was the first one with a chemo cure after childhood leukemia.   This is discussed in the recent book, The Emperor of All Maladies, which I highly recommend for understanding how cancer works and how chemo works (to the best that anybody really knows)  We need more research into CURING metastatic breast cancer so breast cancer can actually be cured!

Posts.Title: 2 Years and Counting kayrnic brandall

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 06:49PM GrandHillMom wrote: My mammograms never showed my bilateral tumors, one of which was seven centimeters in size. Six weeks after my seventh clear mammogram, I felt an enlarged lymph node outside my breast and had an ultrasound and MRIs. I got a digital mammo the same day the MRI found my tumors, and nothing showed up. I never could feel the tumors even when I knew where they were. This is the problem with relying on mammograms for younger women with large, dense breasts. Imaging technology needs to be improved, to prevent both false negatives and false positives using affordable technology, since MRIs are seldom ordered for low or average risk women.
Posts.Title: Slate.com article about mammograms reader123 1Athena1

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 03:26PM GrandHillMom wrote: I do not want to sound alarmist, but my dear Mom died from a pulmonary embolism following an Aranesp injection.  It is approved only for active chemotherapy, but her onc. gave it to her years later for anemia.  She was Stage 1, post lumpectomy, chemo and radiation (by a few years) so her only treatment at the time was tamoxifen. These drugs are beneficial for certain people at certain times, but can be very dangerous otherwise.  When I was on A/C chemo (before Mom died) I had one Aranesp injection for anemia, then the onc. decided to try extra iron supplements and that worked just as well.

By the way, am now NED. Good luck.
